faqs.question: Can foreigners buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners can purchase property in Spain with minimal restrictions. Non-residents can buy residential property without special permits. Most international buyers work with Spanish solicitors to navigate the legal process, tax implications, and obtain an NIE (tax identification number). Our team can recommend trusted legal professionals who specialize in foreign buyer transactions.

faqs.question: What are the costs of buying property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Beyond the purchase price, Spanish property acquisition typically includes: Transfer Tax (6-10%), Legal fees (0.5-1%), Registration fees (0.1%), and Survey costs. Mortgage arrangements incur additional bank fees. For a €349,900 property, expect total acquisition costs of approximately €35,000-45,000. We recommend detailed cost breakdowns during the initial consultation.

faqs.question: Do I need a visa to buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: No visa is required specifically to purchase property in Spain. However, residency status and intended use (primary residence, secondary home, or investment) may influence tax obligations and documentation requirements. EU citizens enjoy unrestricted property ownership rights. Non-EU buyers should consult with immigration specialists regarding residency options if planning to spend significant time at the property.

faqs.question: How much are property taxes in Spain?
faqs.answer: Annual property taxes (IBI - Impuesto sobre Bienes Inmuebles) typically range from 0.4-1.1% of the cadastral value, which is usually lower than market value. Additionally, non-residents may pay a 19% annual wealth tax on properties valued above €600,000. Rental income is taxed at progressive rates up to 45% for non-residents. Spain offers Non-Habitual Resident (NHR) programs with favorable tax treatment for qualifying buyers. Consult a tax advisor for personalized guidance.
